summary: This document is an email chain from January 2021 between Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team and a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) official. It details complaints about Maxwell's treatment in custody, including inappropriate pat-down searches, delays in court appearances, and unsanitary cleaning assignments. The correspondence highlights the defense's concerns about punitive conditions and COVID-19 exposure risks.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the complaints; her legal team is advocating for changes to her treatment in custody regarding pat-down searches, sanitation duties, and court appearance delays.

events.title: Complaints about Maxwell's Custodial Treatment
events.description: Maxwell's legal team sends detailed complaints to a BOP official regarding delays in her video court appearances, inappropriate pat-down searches, and being ordered to clean a toilet without gloves.

events.title: BOP Official Response
events.description: A BOP official responds to the defense's complaints, stating that searches are consistent with policy, that delays were compensated for, and that institutional emergencies can cause schedule deviations.

events.title: Defense Follow-up on Search Protocol
events.description: Maxwell's legal team sends a follow-up email specifically requesting that pat-down searches avoid touching her breasts and that she be allowed to wear a specific top during searches to minimize vulnerability.

locations: New York, NY 10011 (Location of the Law Offices)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team filed complaints about her being subjected to 'repeated, inappropriate touching' of her breasts during daily pat-down searches while in custody.
The defense alleged that Maxwell was ordered to clean a toilet bare-handed at 6:40 AM, outside of prescribed sanitation hours for pretrial inmates, which they viewed as a punitive act.
Maxwell experienced delays in appearing for her scheduled 12:30 PM video court conferences, which her legal team suggested could be retribution for prior complaints.
The defense argued that the frequency and manner of searches, including guards running fingers through her hair near her face, unnecessarily increased Maxwell's risk of COVID-19 exposure.
A BOP official defended the institution's actions, stating searches complied with policy and that schedule deviations were due to institutional emergencies.
